generation: Another week has flown by. I drove past the new house yesterday and noticed the front window was covered in boxes. We may receive the keys at closing, and I'm getting increasingly excited. If everything goes smoothly this week, we'll be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I stayed up late last night, watching movies with Bethany until after 3:00am. There's been a movie marathon going on around here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," a film every mother of a teenager should see. It exceeded my expectations.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone filled with repeats, but now there are two great new shows that I've been watching religiously for the past week. One of them is "Blow Out," a show with a concept that seems to be the most unlikely, yet it has captured my attention. The show revolves around hairstylist Jonathan Antin, who wants to build a second location for his popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, this wouldn't be of interest to me, but as I was flipping through the channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, who appears to be equally narcissistic and dull, standing in an empty space on Rodeo Drive, proclaiming in a public voice, "I'm going to build the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!" and I was hooked. Not since "Rocco" have I found such a moron so compelling to watch.

What a week... I've developed tendonitis in my right shoulder, just under my shoulder blade. The pain is exacerbated when I move my arm excessively, particularly when using a computer mouse. Unfortunately, I've been on a marathon updating my website and working on other online projects, which has left me with limited mobility. I'm struggling to muster the strength to draw anything. The lack of sleep isn't helping, either. I'm not in the best of spirits, but I'm optimistic about recovery. On a more positive note, my mom's surgery was successful. Her eyesight has partially returned, allowing her to see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Although she's still largely blind, I'm hopeful she'll regain her full vision soon.

The kindness of strangers is truly remarkable. Today, I attempted to do laundry with my kids in tow, and it quickly turned into a chaotic ordeal. However, I was reminded of the incredible sweetness of strangers who show kindness for no reason other than the sake of being kind. I'm not talking about people with ulterior motives; these individuals genuinely wanted to help. I was a mess, covered in kid drool and wearing my worn-out laundry day outfit. I'm also not exactly feeling fresh, so there was no incentive for them to be nice. As I sit at my desk, I'm multitasking - composing this post and watching No Doubt music videos.

It's 11:14pm MST, and I'm sitting in my bedroom, fixing the personal computer of our personnel director from work. I don't mind doing favors, but I often wonder how frequently I end up fixing someone else's computer. I'm glad to be able to show love and care for people in this way. However, I sometimes question where the line is drawn between being helpful and being taken advantage of. The last couple of weeks, I've been staying up late reading, so I was looking forward to an early night. Instead, I realized it would be more prudent to return the computer to its owner. No rest for the weary, indeed. I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

Remind me, what did I write about before this? Or, a continuation in the 'is this a date?' saga. After the awkward lunch, my confidence took a hit. I forgot to share an important part of the story with you guys. Before Pat arrived for lunch, Dustin started talking about what a great guy Pat is and how he's trying to find him a girlfriend. As I listened and nodded, I realized we were spending more time discussing finding Dustin's best friend a partner than engaging in typical small talk with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and silently asked myself: am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this what happens now?

I wish everyone would think before acting. Ideally, each person would make a conscious decision to think critically from the moment they wake up, and maintain that mindset throughout the day. If they're not willing to do so, I'd prefer they reconsider their daily activities. I'm frustrated with the prevalence of thoughtless behavior. While I don't claim to be the most intelligent person, I believe it's reasonable to expect a basic level of critical thinking. I'll focus on a few specific examples for now and save others for another time. I'd like to keep this discussion concise and targeted.

Two issues with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 

1. Although Bush is stimulating the economy, it's being done in an unfavorable manner. Robert Rubin, in an interview with NPR's Marketplace, suggested that the same stimulus effect could have been achieved without the long-term debt burden by implementing temporary tax cuts that would benefit low- and middle-income individuals. Robert Rubin's insight is indeed valuable. It's challenging to think of a Bush administration cabinet official on the domestic side who possesses a similar level of gravitas.

2. We cannot afford to give Republicans control solely during wartime, as they have cleverly devised an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'

Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? Like when you're sitting in math class, feeling utterly bored, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that enables you to comprehend math? You realize that you exist, and you're in math class, and you can't help but wonder why. Then it hits you - the sheer amazement of existing. And suddenly, it dawns on you that this random train of thought is somewhat pitiful. Ever had that happen? I find it frustrating. You know what else I dislike? Block schedules. Who would ever conceive such an idea? It's clear that sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is a form of cruel and unusual punishment.

I think that Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow to never lay my hands on that iron game piece again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the game, or maybe I let him win since he's leaving in a few short hours and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story goes, it can't compare to this Texas-sized headache I have at the moment. I've taken some Aleve, and I must say that they're doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation. Your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive-in.

Today's been a long day, having driven home from Indiana. I'll have to be selective about what I write, as I could easily fill a lot of space and time, but I'm running low on energy. To start, I must say that camp exceeded my expectations - it was truly awesome. Lately, God has been working wonders in my life, and it's been incredible. I've undergone a significant transformation, but I'll get back to the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. During our visit, we attended the fair, church, a parade, went to Walmart, and watched movies.

Today marks the end of my summer vacation, and I'm not exactly thrilled about it. I have a dentist appointment scheduled for 9 am, which I'm not looking forward to, but I'd rather get it over with now than try to squeeze it in during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm feeling anxious and apprehensive about the upcoming school year. As a perfectionist, I strive to excel in everything I do, but starting new things can be daunting. I dislike feeling uncertain and out of control, like a pawn on a chessboard. I've always been someone who likes to take charge and make my own moves, but this new chapter is uncharted territory for me.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned as far back as 1996 about the impending threat of the rise of a 'third Islamic state' in the subcontinent. T V Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present Governor of Uttar Pradesh, had predicted this dire threat in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he questions whether the fact that Rajeswar, rather than himself or Mr. Advani, wrote these warnings makes them more credible. Does this revelation lend truth to the warnings, or does it lead to the conclusion that Rajeswar is a closet communalist, unfit to continue as Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

Attitude: bored, mood: indifferent, looking forward to tonight. It's been a long, arduous day in the trenches, leaving little time to write for our readers. However, it's great to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking the reins and making an appearance, discussing various topics. Yesterday's Shakespeare on the Green was a lovely play, although I had to leave before the closing curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully, I'll get to see a complete Shakespeare play someday. Akcron is right about the shower issues; it's a problem. The look people get when enduring self-inflicted discomfort can be quite amusing, I must admit. I'm glad to see her tackling the topic.

Over the past two days, I've been experiencing severe bouts of exhaustion. It's a bone-deep fatigue that's left me feeling drained. Last evening, I returned home and fell asleep, only waking up when my mother called me around 8:30. When I awoke, the room was dark, and I hadn't turned on the lights, so I was disoriented for a few seconds. All I could focus on was my mother's voice in the darkness as I struggled to regain my bearings. I'm still trying to understand why I'm feeling so exhausted. This morning, the weather was pleasant, with a gentle drizzle when I arrived. In contrast, I've heard that Calcutta has been experiencing rain for the past three days.

Last night was the worst. I discarded the sweater I was knitting, having only completed about 14 inches. I lost approximately $10 worth of yarn, which costs $8 per skein. However, the project had become unmanageable, with too many stitches by the time I reached the armholes, and the mohair was prone to knotting, making it difficult to frog the rows. The yarn broke frequently, causing frustration. I remained surprisingly calm, listening to season two of Sex and the City, courtesy of the library. Eventually, I grew tired of it and threw the sweater away. I suppose I could say I gained valuable experience from the attempt. The yarn was a loss, and I didn't even swear, which is unusual for me.

Last night in class, we discussed that week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter explores "implacement" and the second, "displacement." Casey distinguishes that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force, citing phrases like "we are running out of time," "we have saved time," and "we are just in time." He argues that using place as the center of culture fosters a more grounded community. This is a rough summation, and I offer this disclaimer in case my professor or classmates read this post. So far, this book is the first reading that has truly resonated with me.

Whatever it is they put into freeze pops to make them those colours, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. And whilst giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. We stumbled upon a doorway to a bar, sadly closed for business, and paused to examine an office-supplies catalogue that had arrived in the post. Lucky we did. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.

Currently listening to: "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero. Now, onto my post. Senate Republicans, hands up - who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations marathon last week? I must admit, I didn't. However, I did tune in briefly a couple of times. The entire ordeal was a colossal waste of time, orchestrated by Republicans who were upset that Democrats wouldn't nominate four of Bush's judicial picks. They attempted to score political points by holding a multi-day protest. Notably, Democrats have already approved 168 of Bush's judicial nominees. Nevertheless, this wasn't enough for the Republicans, who seem to be under the illusion that they have a significant mandate for such actions.

This was a good weekend. I spent a lot of time outdoors, after a long time, and I also listened to a lot of Nevermore (something I should have started doing much earlier) and read extensively. I finished three books over the weekend - Bruce Sterling's Heavy Weather, Larry Niven's World of Ptavvs, and Octavia Butler's Parable of the Sower. Heavy Weather was a good cyberpunk romp through a near-future USA, devastated by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced, and altogether very convincing, I must confess that I failed to come away with any really significant sensations about the story or the characters. Not that both aren't well constructed and vividly etched - it's a good book, but not a great one, I guess.

The aftermath of the first week back from practicum was a struggle, but it's only in the second week that the smoke has really started to clear. Post-practicum trauma, a hidden epidemic, is only now coming to light. I was stricken, but an eventual meeting with the course co-ordinator allowed me to release my burden. By doing so, I have prevented another person from being stuck with a pedagogically deficit practicum school. Yesterday, I bumped into another aggrieved classmate who was determined to warn the student due to attend her school in the next practicum about the terrible experience. I calmed her down, suggesting we should first approach the administrator.

Things are incredibly busy here at times, but there's always time for stress-relieving activities. I've discovered that I'm not very skilled at 8-ball and ping pong. Rick, the Canadian, consistently beats me, and we often play a quick round on the ping pong table in our building's front lobby. Last night, I participated in an 8-ball tournament at the recreation tent, which we call the hot spot. It's equipped with a popcorn machine, multiple TVs, a jukebox, DVD rentals, a pool table, a dartboard, and a ping pong table. I did fairly well in my one game until I scratched on the eight ball. Despite that, I still had a good time, especially with the two Dutch soldiers who joined the tournament.

Fall 1974: I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. As someone who has never been inclined towards math, I found myself struggling to make sense of it. My aversion to math is undeniable. Just as I was starting to grasp a concept, the doorbell rang, prompting me to put down my book and answer it. However, upon opening the door, I found no one there. I returned to my studies, only to have the doorbell ring again just as I was gaining a glimmer of understanding. My breakthrough vanished instantly. I went to the door once more, only to find it empty. This was the last thing a struggling math student like myself needed – an uninvited practical joker disrupting my already fragile focus.

This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday through Thursday completing the move to my new classroom. The new room is bigger and closer to my grade level team, which are essential factors to consider as I invest hours in preparing my room for this year. Had I known about the move prior to the end of my school year, I would have discarded many of the books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, they all came with me. So this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging extensively. I have to thank my teammate Jill for her assistance with all of this. You see, she was still teaching this month in my old room. So she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me, which was a huge help.

You can't escape it, a part of you will forever be a part of me. Even if we never had a child, never married, or never officially paired, my love for you was immense, and its echo still resonates in my heart. I'll always be reminded of the few nights we spent together, our hearts and limbs entwined in a soulful embrace, under the salty darkness of a beach evening or a kiss in the rain. Whenever a pang of sorrow pierces my heart, you'll be there, that piece of you bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me and still remains.

I'm uncomfortable with the investigative reporting I'm doing, and its potential consequences. I'm not entirely convinced by the article's premise, which makes it difficult for me to fully immerse myself in it. I struggle to grasp the underlying passion and angst that drives it. Growing up in a country where questioning authority was discouraged, I'm not accustomed to exercising my freedom of speech. In my homeland, asking questions could lead to severe repercussions, including imprisonment under internal security acts. This newfound freedom to question openly is unfamiliar to me. I've always been someone who speaks my mind, which doesn't always make me easy to get along with.

We had an outing yesterday with my colleagues at the bank to Guintubdan, La Carolota. For most of us, it was our first time visiting the area. We embarked on a trek to the falls, which took around 30 minutes, leaving us all breathless. However, the exhaustion was worth it as we finally reached our destination. The icy water was invigorating, causing our bodies to numb from the cold. We only stayed for less than an hour before heading to the nearby waterfalls, which required another 30 minutes of trekking. The trip was worth it, as the falls exuded a calming ambiance and the scenery was breathtaking. It felt like being one with nature, and the experience was truly rejuvenating. The cold air and water were so soothing that they could lull you to sleep. We were all catching our breaths. Whew! but we made it. You can feel your body getting numb because of the coldness. Soaking myself in the cold water was like communing with mother earth.

I'm fairly certain my sisters are intoxicated. Today was Pride in San Diego, and I know my sisters well - when it's time to drink, they don't hold back. Drinking is one trait I didn't inherit from the Buenviajes. While I do enjoy a drink on rare occasions, those instances are few and far between. With only a month left before Ed leaves, I think the reality of the situation is starting to sink in for Ed and the rest of us. To be honest, it hit me a long time ago. I just hope Ed will be here for Bailey's surgery. We've been monitoring his swelling, and there's definitely a noticeable amount.

On Saturday, we took Connor to Fireman's Park, expecting the Easter egg hunt to begin at 11am. However, it turned out the event was actually held on Friday. Fortunately, I had brought a bag of eggs as a precaution. As a result, Connor still had a great time searching for eggs in the park. The next morning, he woke up excited, believing the Easter bunny had visited. Witnessing the excitement on a child's face is truly heartwarming. Following the egg hunt, we attended church as a family. Although the Easter bunny is a fun tradition, we ensure our children understand the true meaning of the holiday.

Friday, November 22, 2002 - I'm thrilled to have my boots at home. Unfortunately, I had them delivered to my house instead of work, so I'll have to wait another four hours to get them. These are the Face boots and Tredair Flame boots - I'm really excited. However, my day took a turn for the worse when I got a flat tire. Luckily, I'm at work, and my colleagues are going to inflate it for me and check if it holds air. If not, they'll change my tire and put on the spare. Thankfully, my spare is full-sized. I may need to buy a new tire tonight, which is a bit of a silver lining.

I've had a change of heart since my previous post, where I defended parents and almost took their side. Now, I realize that parents don't truly understand us. They may think they can read our emotions and know us inside out, but the truth is, they don't. After a recent argument with Nicole about Kelli, I went upstairs, and my parents asked me what was wrong. I felt like saying, "Can't you just give me some space?" I don't owe them an explanation every time. The situation with Nicole and Kelli is simple: they don't get along.

Music for the day: 94.7 fm. I almost didn't make it to work on time due to a massive accident at 14th and Constitution, which caused traffic chaos in Virginia. Fortunately, I skillfully maneuvered my car from the far left lane to the far right and managed to get onto Route 50. This may not be relevant to anyone outside of this area, so I'll spare the details. I'm relieved to be sitting here instead of stuck in my car. Yesterday, Sara decided to Google me and discovered that an email I wrote to Ivan Maisel on ESPN.com was published online. I had no idea; I didn't think my argument was particularly well-written, but apparently someone thought otherwise.

I recently had the opportunity to watch Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, and I must say it was absolutely brilliant. I managed to catch it on the opening day, right after school on Friday - thanks to Mike for the ticket. Daniel Radcliffe, who plays Harry Potter, has grown up so quickly and is quite charming. Malfoy, too, was quite entertaining. The movie was great overall, but I would give it 4.5 stars as some important details were left out. Although I didn't dress up for the movie, I did wear a Ravenclaw tie, despite being more of a Gryffindor fan.

Pears and peanut butter attempt #2. This time, I have hard pears and my own jar of peanut butter for dipping, but it's still crunchy, not smooth, which I think makes a difference. I'm slightly perturbed, having just noticed that per 100g (about a fifth of our smaller jars), there are 614 calories. I'm trying not to think about it. I've just returned from an evening out at my old music teacher's house, who's also a friend. I did tape the show I missed, and I've discovered that they're airing repeats of series 9 every morning at 9:55. It was good seeing my friend, a bit strange but enjoyable.

Some people are jumping to connect the dots: the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. Observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This will be the first time such a team has been present for a U.S. presidential election. A group of congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, has petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to dispatch international observers to Florida to oversee this year's presidential balloting there. I humbly disagree. Based on available information, the OSCE seems to be coming to learn from the U.S. election process, not to oversee it, which was the original partisan and childish call for U.N.

My heinous mood has passed. The combination of an impending period and forgetting to take Prozac until late in the day had left me feeling extremely sad and tearful. However, a surprise visit from my boyfriend, an ice cream sundae, and the comfort of holding his hand after a terrifying dream in which people started shooting machine guns at the news bureau greatly improved my mood. GOP Faces Backlash Over Recruitment Tactics at Naturalization Ceremonies in Jacksonville. 

A citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville, attended by nearly 200 people, seemed to proceed as usual, with the crowd leaving as new Americans. However, just before the new citizens departed the June 29 event, an immigration official directing the swearing-in ceremony encouraged them to visit a voter registration table, a common sight at naturalization ceremonies. 

The table, however, was unusual in that it was staffed by Republican volunteers, and the party affiliation box on the registration forms had been pre-checked to make all new voters members of the GOP. This raised suspicions, particularly for Linda Cross, who was in attendance to watch her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath. The incident has led to complaints and calls for the relocation of recruitment naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville.

It's not really a hook, but I've been accumulating sub-days and decided to cash one in today, Wednesday the 10th in Japan (note that the post-time reflects the U.S. date, so it's technically not accurate). I'm taking a couple of days off to simply unwind. Nothing like 48 hours of daydreaming to recharge my creative energy. As a foreigner, I have it relatively good, and my timing was fortunate. The illustration aspect is the icing on the cake – I'd probably complain more if that hadn't fallen into place. I'm aware that I'm not being fairly compensated, though. I'm getting hungry; I might head to Speak Easy, the 'American-style' diner just across the street from the post office in my prefecture, for some Mexican food.

I take great pride in making everyone who visits Casa Pescatore feel as comfortable as possible, just as they would in their own home. Yesterday, I hoped to achieve this goal. A large crowd gathered on Perry Avenue, with many displaying what could be considered extreme enthusiasm. At 4:30 pm, my best friend Eric and his son Nunu arrived with a massive pan of baked ziti. The tables were set, and I had prepared all the food, with the doorbell ringing nonstop. Before I knew it, my best friend from Florida walked in, bringing a smile to my face. I had missed him dearly. As a pleasant surprise, he brought his wife along, who is expecting. This was the closest I could get to being an uncle, and I spoiled her with multiple trays of food and tiramisu.

I found the concept intriguing as a potential defense against being accused of witchcraft. As a non-American blogger, I've been hesitant to engage in certain discussions, particularly those surrounding flags. However, since I initiated the topic, I feel compelled to share my thoughts. Firstly, I believe that enacting a law against flag-burning is utterly absurd. The moment you grant a symbol - any symbol - automatic reverence and protection, you've taken a small yet significant step towards totalitarianism. Symbols are inherently subjective - they don't inherently represent anything; their meaning is derived from perception or assigned representation.

1. Everyone has a favorite movie or series - what's yours? Mine's the Evil Dead series, as you might have guessed. I have one of the largest collections of memorabilia from this series. 2. I watched Troy with my family tonight, but unfortunately, it didn't leave a lasting impression on me. Although I'm too exhausted to delve into specifics, I believe the film had potential. However, I think the filmmakers invested too much energy in creating a magnificent set, while neglecting to establish a solid tone and theme. The story was retold, but it lacked a gripping quality, and I didn't feel like I gained anything from watching it. The character development was also somewhat weak. The score was unimpressive and seemed to be a knock-off of Gladiator.

Urllink introduces the latest atom/RDF/RSS reader, Urllink PulpFiction 1.0, from Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. This application boasts an array of native app features. Notably, it is not free, a topic currently sparking debate on the internet. A 15-day trial is available, after which users can either discontinue or purchase the software for $25. A standout feature is the ability to manage individual posts as separate entities, allowing users to move, store, label, and delete them as desired. This functionality is likely to appeal to news tracker enthusiasts. As expected, the software supports OPML import and export.

Today, I miss my sister terribly - it's strange not having her around, even if she could be irritating at times. Although she was only here for a week, her presence was truly felt, and I mean that in the best possible way. Working on the scrapbook from our trip to Tasmania brings back fond memories of a time that feels like just yesterday - last week, in fact. Perhaps it's the thought of not seeing her for a while, with her moving to Bristol in September or October, that's making me feel this way. She represented a deeper connection to my family back home. I miss them all dearly. Tomorrow marks the start of a new term, and I'm still wondering how the holidays flew by so quickly.

Ever have one of those days when you're completely lost and unsure about anything? If not, you might want to skip the rest of this, as it may not resonate with you. For those who choose to continue, I'd like to share an observation. Sometimes I wish I had been given a manual for life. A well-crafted manual would provide valuable information, such as the purpose of things, their capabilities, and how they function. It would also explain the consequences of certain actions, offer troubleshooting tips, and provide contact information for an expert who can resolve any issues. Unfortunately, I didn't receive a manual with my existence.

There's nothing wrong with PCs - if I were an avid gamer with ample time, I'd certainly have a PC system for the vast array of available games. However, except for a few unique products, the extensive selection at CompUSA starts to feel repetitive after a while. Initially, I'm envious, but then I notice that it's essentially various flavors of the same soda - first-person shooters, mystery games, strategy games, and simulations. The numerous variations of Age of Empires become comical. AOE with orcs, AOE with spaceships, AOE with fuzzy wombats - it's reminiscent of movie trailers that begin with the line: 'in a world...'

Magic fans, be warned: Wizards seems hesitant to create a decent digital game. Being the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I generally dislike prequels, as they technically move the story backward rather than forward, which is an inherent issue with this genre. However, they often provide additional story depth. The combat feels somewhat unrefined and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of my writing this recommendation (26/10/2013), a game-breaking bug exists, preventing the completion of a side mission, although the main storyline remains unaffected. Some gadgets are assigned to inconvenient hotkeys, requiring excessive keyboard navigation, which can disrupt combos during combat.

They essentially perfected Shadow Warrior (2013). The boss fights are impressive, and the weapons feel solid, although not quite as exceptional as those in D44M. Enemies are not overly resilient, provided you effectively manage elemental and upgrade aspects. The upgrade system is well-balanced, and once you grasp it, it's not too tedious. The elemental mechanics and limited ammo encourage the use of diverse weapons. There are many unique and cool weapons that remain viable throughout the game. The music is excellent, particularly the main theme and Stan Bush's contributions.

I think this Assassin's Creed has perfected its mechanics across the board, from ship battles and sailing to hunting and parkour. I found myself more invested in the protagonist than in previous games. Although the story begins on a rough note, it significantly improves as the game progresses - a trend I've noticed in every AC game. Edward is a fascinating character, and the supporting cast is equally well-developed. The collectibles in this game feel more meaningful than in previous installments, possibly due to their greater significance in the overall narrative. While not required, they're enjoyable to collect and reward the player in a balanced manner. The initial rough start to the story does get much better as you play. Edward and the side characters are quite interesting.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is passable, provided you have the means to purchase gun parts. This is my primary concern with the game: its pay-to-win model. If I could overlook this, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun to use and the HRV concept is excellent. I'd prefer this game over any Call of Duty title, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting. If you're comfortable with this model, then by all means, have fun. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to avoid this one; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been greatly enjoyable. The save system and possibility of sudden death can be frustrating at times. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around the 10-hour mark of a 20-hour campaign. A reload option at that point would have been greatly appreciated. To mitigate such losses, I've resorted to using a third-party mod and save tool. Additionally, the aiming reticule is somewhat small, and the zoom feature could be more powerful. Despite these issues, the game has been a blast. As someone who isn't typically a fan of zombie games, I've found the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up elements to be engaging. I've been playing it as often as I can, always looking to complete just one more mission or supply run before shutting down the game.

An exceptional strategy game, in my opinion. Having played numerous other wargames, including European Escalation and ALB, I must say this one stands out. The vast array of units is impressive, with a staggering number available. The graphics are stunning, the sound effects are great, and the overall gameplay is truly epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is surprisingly entertaining, and I'm not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy', or if you're new to the strategy genre, be prepared to invest time in mastering it. Do not get discouraged, as you will inevitably lose units.

I had a negative bias towards this game before playing it, and I was hesitant to buy it. The concept of the portal gun and portals seemed unusual, despite my fondness for science fiction. However, I was pleasantly surprised. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal, and the humor is well-balanced, occasionally bordering on cheesy. Each story character has a unique sense of humor and distinct personality. The level design is also impressive. Notably, I hadn't played the first Portal game before playing the sequel, but I plan to do so when I have the time.

This game is a nostalgic treat for thirty-somethings who recall watching the Transformers cartoon in the UK, if only to endure the annoying Timmy Mallet for those five minutes. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and others have returned, and their voices are instantly recognisable. The iconic cartoon transformation sound effect is also present. The cell-shaded graphics are perfect and quintessentially Generation One. Beyond the nostalgic value, the game is genuinely enjoyable. The combat mechanics are well-executed, with mid-fight transformations often being a necessity, seamlessly integrated into combos. Unlike High Moon's War for/Fall of Cybertron games, this title has a strong focus on melee combat, although some enemies, such as Seekers, require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it briefly, but it didn't leave a lasting impression. However, I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. A bug kept popping up, stating that there was an update to the terms of service. Clicking 'accept' didn't resolve the issue; I had to restart the client. Although this wasn't a major issue, I was puzzled by the requirement to link my Steam and Gface accounts. The reason cited was for DLC, but I couldn't understand why this was necessary. Furthermore, this linking process is irreversible, which means a company I'm not invested in now has access to my Steam information. The game itself is mediocre. It's easily recognizable as a Call of Duty clone, but somehow the developers managed to make the gunplay worse.

4k+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and Neptune gear are all included. What's not to love? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo This is an excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. However, be aware that there are lengthy dialogue sections, which can be skipped. While a gamepad is recommended, I found the keymouse/mouse setup to be fully functional and rebindable. The price is reasonable, and the inclusion of more than half the DLC for free is a bonus. I'd recommend this game to JRPG, anime, and visual novel fans, provided they don't mind the occasional breaks in action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues at release, and after numerous patches, the game runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is a great and enjoyable game, despite the somewhat frustrating format where the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies upon progressing through the story. The 'dual play' segments, where you can play as Batman and another character, were particularly enjoyable. I also appreciated the flexibility of using a controller for most segments, while switching to mouse and keyboard for tank combat. Mastering the art of using the brakes to skid around corners while driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, especially during APC commander chases, is quite enjoyable. Once you get the hang of it, navigating the city becomes a thrilling experience. The game's overall design allows for a seamless transition between different gameplay mechanics.

This game is a damn fine AAA FPS shooter - that's the bottom line. It boasts impressive visuals, sounds, and gameplay - great FPS mechanics, a nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. However, it's not for the faint-hearted, as some cutscenes are quite vivid and cruel. When a game is overall great, its flaws become more noticeable, and here are the ones I observed: - No SLI support, which is surprising. I had to put the game aside until I upgraded my graphics card, as it ran poorly on my old dual-GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a fairly decent single-GPU card. - Some small obstacles are unclimbable, which seems illogical.

I am not a native English speaker, as Dutch is my native language. Please disregard any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into several categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability. 

Graphics: The game features a comic-like style, with very slick graphics that avoid unnecessary details. The color schemes are nice, and this aesthetic works well for the game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without putting excessive strain on your system. I run the game on an i5 Pentium processor, with an Nvidia GeForce 710m card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly on Windows 8.1.

- controls: The game can be played with keyboard and mouse, but also with an X-box controller.

The hours I've invested in this game demonstrate my genuine enjoyment. It's everything I had hoped for in a search game from the Call of Duty series. However, I must caution against purchasing this game with the expectation that it's similar to Call of Duty, Battlefield, or other shooter games. It's a unique game that deserves to be appreciated on its own terms. I've lost count of how many times I've heard new players express frustration and complain about being killed quickly. It's almost as if they're surprised to be shot and killed, despite this being a realistic outcome. 

Edit: After playing this game for a while now and investing a significant amount of money, I can confidently say it's one of the best multiplayer games available. It's a great alternative to play when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm 2 hours in and thoroughly enjoying this game. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, and the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting. The story and world have piqued my interest, and the puzzles are entertaining. However, the standout aspect of this game is its comedy. If you've played RPGs since their inception, you'll appreciate the various jokes, parodies, and references. Even if you're new to RPGs, the humor is still enjoyable. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you owe it to yourself to play this game. I had to pause after 2 hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far. The comedy is so funny. Gameplay is also solid, art design is beautiful, music is surprisingly high quality and appropriate, the story/world has me interested, and the puzzles are fun.

I apologize, but despite my enthusiasm for free-to-play games and indie developers, I didn't enjoy this game. The description aligned with my interests, but the execution fell short. As a fan of puzzle and exploration games, I found this title to be unintuitive, and even after researching progression methods, the gameplay itself failed to engage me. A notable omission is a pause button, which seems crucial given the timed sequences. The game's balance also feels off, with an overemphasis on cutscenes that leave the player waiting idly. I often found myself waiting, feeling uninvolved in the experience. The lack of interactivity was disappointing.

This game is truly breathtaking. From its captivating storyline to its stunning graphics, I was completely enthralled. The narrative wasn't just a generic tale, but rather an immersive experience that made me feel like I was the protagonist, eagerly anticipating the next twist in the story. The gameplay was exceptional, and I gained valuable insights about myself, particularly my unexpected fear of heights, which was triggered by the ice caverns. My anxiety was palpable, but my determination to progress for Uncle Fred kept me going. I would be thrilled to see a DLC or sequel, and I would be the first in line to purchase it, recommending it to everyone I know. Thank you to the entire team involved in creating this masterpiece; you've truly crafted a beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or 'victory'. Unlike previous games, which followed the Earth's timeline through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this game takes place in the future, where you're on a mission to colonize a new planet. I appreciate that 2K took a fresh approach to the game, introducing new mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. However, these additions sometimes made the game feel overwhelming. One potential improvement could be incorporating new artwork, particularly in the environment experienced when communicating with other leaders.

Great game with tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience. Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. After investing over 60 hours, I can confidently say this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games. Its design is reminiscent of survival horror, requiring you to conserve ammo, treat your own wounds, and take medication when infected. The zombies feel natural and are well-animated, especially considering it's a free-to-play game. I highly recommend playing with 1 or 2 friends, but the community is extremely friendly, making it easy to make friends or chat with others via voice comms.

02/07/2014 - Unfortunately, I'm unable to wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy this game due to two major issues that I've encountered during my brief playtime. I'm confident that I would be thoroughly engaged if not for these problems. Firstly, the lack of Australian servers is a significant drawback, as a single red bar results in a substantial disadvantage and unbearable lag. Notably, even the offline training mode experienced stuttering and lag, which is perplexing. The poor ping further exacerbates the issue, ultimately ruining the game. Everything is plagued by artifacts - menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never experienced this issue with my graphics card before, so I suspected it might be related to my overclock. However, resetting my GPU to its stock settings made no difference.

I completed this late last night. Although the story lacks depth and interest, the storytelling is exceptional. The atmosphere is richly detailed, and the numerous collectibles effectively flesh out the world. I gained valuable insights into the Batman universe, which made the limited number of bosses somewhat disappointing. However, future games can address this issue. The combat strikes a good balance of challenge, albeit on the easier side. Leveling up Batman was not particularly satisfying. On the other hand, upgrading and acquiring gadgets during the campaign introduced enjoyable new gameplay mechanics. Accessing previously inaccessible areas created a sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game... Nay, it is a veritable experience, and it was one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Hohoho! Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I been so deeply moved, feeling both depressed and fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion. The soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor of the game is great as well and it definitely does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story. The Doctor Who references are endless, adding another layer of depth to the game.

Bastion is a remarkably engaging game, boasting a captivating storyline. The game takes place in a post-calamity world, where you embark on rebuilding the bastion. The game offers a considerable amount of choice, allowing you to decide what to build to gain an advantage, which weapons to utilize, and what power-ups to equip them with. Additionally, you can choose from various drinks that provide bonus effects. The art style and music in the game are truly fantastic, with vibrant visuals that defy the conventional notion of a dull apocalypse. The game's narration is also noteworthy, as it dynamically responds to the player's actions.

I initially purchased this game during its early development stages, when the sole currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree'. This was the period when the game truly shone. At that point, all guns were equally overpowered, eliminating any balance issues; players could engage and defeat each other at will. The game also offered unlimited gun slots and five loadouts, allowing for extensive customization. Given the game's boast of having 'bajillions of guns', it's surprising that players are now limited to just six weapon slots and three loadouts, with additional slots and loadouts available only through purchase. I once had an impressive collection of guns, spanning three pages, and was brainstorming new ideas, as this aspect of the game was where I derived the most enjoyment.

This game was a surprising gem. One often encounters rave reviews of certain products that can be misleading. In this case, the reviews accurately reflect the fun of this neat little game. It's an unusual blend of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with style. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway. I was pleasantly surprised with the outcome and ended up trying out more as they were unlocked from playing games. The art style and interface are oddly charming. As such, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and a wallpaper from creating a card set for the game. I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a go anyway, was changed to I had expected this trait to continue, but decided to give a melee tank a try anyway.

I recently started playing, and I'm thoroughly enjoying this game. With my headphones on, I become completely immersed in the game for hours on end. It's been a while since a game has had such a profound effect on me. The music effectively sets the mood, the sound effects are spot on, and the controls are flawless. I eagerly anticipate every combat encounter, and the developers have optimized the combat system extremely well. Initially, I had doubts about the naval combat system, but it's incredibly fun to take down multiple fleets simultaneously. The only way to lose is by failing to retreat when necessary. If the combat appears overwhelming, it's best to regroup and launch a counter-assault. Thanks to the developers for creating an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought significant changes to the series, particularly for its protagonist, Dante. Although fans of the original series may be upset by the changes to their beloved character, they are undoubtedly for the better, as proven by this new game from Ninja Theory. DmC serves as the perfect entry point for newcomers to the series, showcasing the origins of an arrogant and cynical Dante and chronicling his transformation from cynicism to selflessness. The game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he is introduced to the corrupt world he had previously chosen to ignore, and his journey is one of growth and self-discovery.

Where do I even begin with this absolutely captivating game? Its story is undeniably charming, boasting an impressive level of detail that makes it a true bundle of joy. With a perfect balance of humor and seriousness, it effortlessly navigates between heartwarming moments and laugh-out-loud humor, often courtesy of its lovable canine companions and clever secrets. The character design is impeccable, featuring a diverse cast with unique personalities and intriguing backstories. What truly sets it apart from other RPGs is its bold decision to forgo violence, a refreshing twist on the genre. Drawing inspiration from the beloved Earthbound, it's clear that this game is something special. Its soundtrack is, without a doubt, one of the best I've had the pleasure of listening to in a long time. The character design is on point, with various characters having various personalities and secrets to them. It has so much detail put into it, and it is a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, secrets. It is serious when it needs to be, but isn't a stranger to funny moments.

I recommend this solely because it's free and might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. However, personally, the game had little impact on me. Half of the story relies heavily on shock value, which failed to elicit an emotional response from me. I may be desensitized, or perhaps the execution was too simplistic to warrant a reaction. The other half of the game attempts to portray a person's mental decline through various themes, including obsession, hallucination, and depression. While the concept is intriguing in theory, the game's brevity and simplicity detract from its potential. I completed it in 10 minutes, taking the time to absorb every detail.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then steps aside, allowing you to take the reins. It's an incredible way to challenge your mind while still having fun. Although this game isn't as story-driven, it did give birth to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play this game and beat it when I'm feeling bored, and I love to come back and see what gave birth to a legend and what is a legend. Portal's gameplay is quite simple to explain. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate a part of the puzzle. Two buttons are in the game, one that you press and one that requires a cube to be placed on it. The game's simplicity is part of its charm, making it easy to pick up and play. The portal gun is an ingenious tool that allows you to navigate through the game's challenging levels. The game's design is clever, with each level carefully crafted to test your problem-solving skills. The game's world is also rich in dark humor, with a sadistic AI that guides you through the game. Overall, Portal is a game that is both fun and challenging, making it a must-play for anyone who loves puzzle games.

If you can overlook the bugs (which I personally experienced only twice: one minor and the other quite annoying), I can definitely recommend this space exploration game. Both bugs have since been resolved, with one fix significantly increasing my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120. As most reviews focus on system specs, I'll share mine: I5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro Gaming (~150€), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€), totaling ~650€, which falls within the medium price range. Although my rig is relatively new, I consistently achieve 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled, which makes me question the numerous comments from users with overkill setups who claim to get only 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? It's been that long since an RTS game of such quality has been released. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes awfully close to becoming my personal favorite RTS game. Combining this with a huge Risk-like grand strategy mode hits the spot perfectly. I try not to be overly biased, but the fact that this game allows you to transform into a dragon, supporting, attacking, and commanding unit production, direction, and spawning simultaneously, is a significant advantage. Honestly, I do enjoy complicated RTS games, such as Civilization V. However, such games often attempt to cram complex mechanics, charts, and resources into one complicated game mode, which can be overwhelming. The ability to turn into a dragon, aiding troops, is a unique feature that sets Divinity: Dragon Commander apart.

Undertale transcends the sum of its parts to create something truly remarkable. The solid retro graphics and pleasant music combine to produce breathtaking and impactful moments. The script masterfully navigates a wide range of emotions, from comedic to dramatic, heartbreaking, and hopeful, often simultaneously, while cleverly subverting RPG tropes. The world, characters, story, and gameplay are equally impressive, warranting extensive discussion. However, I'll simply say this: if you're an RPG enthusiast, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours to spare, play this game, regardless of your gaming preferences.

I've only had this game for a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have elevated an already great game to an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, and their engagement is evident in the discussion forums and dev diaries. Although the game's mechanics have a fairly steep learning curve, which I'm still trying to master, this complexity offers a wide range of strategies to achieve goals and capitalize on situations. The game, in my mind, is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself sucked into every session I play, regardless of how the play-through is going. The devs are very active in the community, and it really shows.

Warframe is an enjoyable game for the initial few hours of play. However, after this period, the game's limitations become apparent, with repetition in combat, enemies, and gameplay being the primary concerns. A significant redeeming quality is the developers' dedication to regular updates, which often include substantial content additions, such as sweeping system changes, new warframes, and various tweaks and features. This makes Warframe suitable for casual play. Nevertheless, its ability to sustain long-term interest is questionable, unless you have a strong affinity for grinding. Fortunately, the game is free, making it worth trying out, especially if you're seeking a brief gaming experience.

This game is extremely dull. I purchased it, expecting a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy', a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls short. The gameplay involves absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow bigger and absorb more. However, the experience is marred by poor execution, unoriginal levels, and a surreal atmosphere that's more disturbing than entertaining. The game's depiction of 'living' creatures, from small pets to humans, is unsettling and raises questions about the creators' inspirations. I was left feeling rather depressed and questioning the value of existence. The game's overall tone is bleak and uninviting. The levels lack creativity, and the gameplay is not as smooth as it could be.

As a person deeply interested in politics, I was initially excited when I first heard about this game. I thought to myself, 'A simulator of the road to becoming president? That sounds intriguing!' Unfortunately, my enthusiasm was short-lived. The game begins by asking you to choose a side: Republican or Democrat, with no option for an independent or third-party candidate. Although slightly disappointed, I remained optimistic and continued to explore the game's features. One aspect that deserves credit is the character customization, which, despite being limited, is enjoyable to experiment with.

My stats at the time of writing this review are as follows: 8.6 hours to complete the game, 10 collectibles found out of 25, and zero achievements out of 15. 

I enjoyed the visuals up until the last level, the ice caves, which were a notable exception. Although the story was not particularly impressive, the ending, which occurred after the closing credits, somewhat redeemed the time I spent playing the game.

However, I was disappointed with the visuals in the last level, which I found uninteresting. The gameplay also became significantly more challenging, leading to a frustrating experience of repetition until I finally succeeded. Furthermore, I found the achievements to be overly difficult, with 13 out of 15 having been achieved by less than 2.1% of players.

Pros: +graphics. Cons: -bugs, particularly environmental issues, can cause players to become stuck or encounter invisible walls, even with a clear line of sight to the enemy. -The game holds the player's hand excessively, making it feel overly guided. -Enemy AI is underwhelming. -Enemies often seem to have omniscient knowledge of the player's location once spotted. -Enemies possess unreasonably high accuracy, reminiscent of the first Ghost Warrior, which can be frustrating. The remaining issues include poorly implemented checkpoints and saves, as well as an unengaging storyline that fails to capture interest. Overall, I would not recommend this game unless it's heavily discounted, even then, playing it feels like a chore, driven solely by the desire to finish and move on to the next game in my library.

Review for 29/11/2015: Avoid purchasing this game due to frequent server outages, rendering it unplayable. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. During my brief time playing, I found it enjoyable. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: "Go on take the money and run..." https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54 --- English - 73 minutes playing the game. Initially, I was impressed, but some guns are overpowered and matchmaking can be unfair. However, this issue is not unique to this game, as seen in BF3, where new players are often matched with higher-level players who seem almost invulnerable.

I can appreciate why others enjoy this game, but it didn't resonate with me. As a Vive owner, I prefer playing room-sized games with controllers. Although the game's vast universe is initially awe-inspiring, I found its scale to be a hindrance to my enjoyment. The learning curve and time required to accomplish anything meaningful at the beginning were too steep for me. The game demands patience and a significant time commitment, which I couldn't provide. With numerous other VR games vying for my attention, I didn't feel compelled to invest more time in this one.

Hands down, my all-time favorite first-person shooter. However, this game is not suited for 'run and gun' players. The recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic, making it a challenging experience. A single hit to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon is often fatal, unless it's just a graze. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are necessary to maintain accuracy. There's no infinite ammunition pool; if you frequently reload mid-magazine, you'll end up with a pouch full of partially used magazines. You can't sprint indefinitely, as prolonged running will leave you gasping for breath, affecting your aim. To steady your aim, rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill.

I didn't purchase EU when it first came out, instead opting for it on sale, which included EW. As a result, I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with the game. I thoroughly enjoyed it, finding it challenging in the early stages but rewarding when executed correctly. In contrast, I have a positive experience with XCOM2. The game runs smoothly on medium settings, even with my relatively outdated GTX560 graphics card, which has 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game was set to high, resulting in some sluggish performance, but it wasn't unplayable. Dropping the settings to medium resolved the issue. I'm not sure if I'm just fortunate when it comes to avoiding game issues, but many negative reviews seem to stem from unrealistic expectations.

More than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over the course of five days, they will engage in discussions on a wide range of issues, including China's growing economic power and the future of Iraq following this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the over 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be subdued. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEF's event in Davos.

Deadline nears for Fiat-GM deal. Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to resolve a disagreement over a potential takeover. The deadline marks the point at which Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, part of an alliance agreed in 2000. GM, whose own European operations are struggling financially, no longer wants to own the unprofitable Fiat unit. Reports of deadlocked talks sent Fiat shares down 1.2% on Tuesday, following Monday's 4% gain on hopes of a payoff. The US firm is thought to be offering approximately $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to extricate itself from the arrangement. It has argued the deal was voided by Fiat's decision to sell off its finance arm and halve GM's stake via a capital-raising effort.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticised the billions of pounds spent on the Iraq war, stating that the funds could have been better utilised to alleviate poverty. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales expressed his views on BBC Radio 4 and is expected to reiterate his stance during his Christmas midnight mass. In a Christmas message, the cardinal denounced the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of resources. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have publicly spoken out against the war. The cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the archbishop of canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's thought for the day slot, he criticised the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease".

Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic 'Halloween,' has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film achieved a record-breaking worldwide gross of over $60 million (£31.3 million) at that time, a remarkable feat for an independent film. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on 'Escape from New York' and 'The Fog.' Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of Britain's broadband users regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. The report states that having an always-on, fast connection is transforming the way people utilize the internet. With over five million households in the UK having broadband, and this number rapidly increasing, the Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It discovered that more than half of broadband users log on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. The report also found that broadband users regularly upload content and have personal sites.

Yukos to return to US courts as Russian oil and gas company continues its fight for survival. The firm is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. In an attempt to utilize international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US. Despite this, the unit was sold to state oil firm Rosneft for $9.4 billion, following a disrupted state auction. Yukos' lawyers now argue that the auction breached US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any company that acquires its assets, employing all available legal means.

Voters flock to blog awards site as voting commences for the annual Bloggies, which acknowledge the best web blogs of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but the official site experienced a temporary closure due to an overwhelming influx of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a top US dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to US research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life.

Chinese dam firm 'defies Beijing' - The China Three Gorges Project Corp is reportedly refusing to comply with a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams. According to the Beijing News, the company behind the Three Gorges Dam is continuing work on the Xiluodu Dam, despite being instructed to stop. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 large-scale construction projects that were ordered to cease operations due to inadequate environmental checks. Instead of complying, the company may opt to pay a fine, the Beijing News reported. This is not the first instance of defiance by the firm, as it has also ignored orders to stop construction at two other projects - the Three Gorges underground power plant and the Three Gorges project electrical power supply plant. The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the Chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney met Gary Neville's cross at the near post with a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne and into the net, putting United ahead. Seven minutes later, Dunne unfortunately hooked a volley over David James' head and into his own net. Steve McManaman squandered City's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. United's approach play was laboured, and they managed to create just one chance in the opening 45 minutes - a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons' from England in tackling waiting lists, according to the new Health Minister for Wales. Dr Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the job following Jane Hutt's dismissal, acknowledged "big challenges" but maintained that the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats emphasized that Dr Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms Hutt defended her record, stating that waiting times and lists comprised "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr Gibbons, a former GP in Blaengwynfi, Upper Afan Valley, and AM for Aberavon, noted that NHS staff desired a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." The lengthy waiting lists in Wales had been a significant issue during Ms Hutt's five-and-a-half-year tenure as the assembly's first Health Minister.

Manchester United's Alex Ferguson commended his team's gritty performance in their 1-0 win at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football, with end-to-end action and plenty of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We demonstrated a lot of character and determination, and we were resolute in our refusal to lose." Ferguson reflected on the fixture, "I think we've accomplished something significant by winning there, while Arsenal and Chelsea still have to come, and Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. 'A Different Story' will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, running from 10-20 February. The film features the singer reflecting on his career and personal life, from his early days in Wham! to more recent events. George Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and Executive Producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance. The 93-minute film explores Michael's early days in Wham! and his later career, including his legal battles with Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Digital music downloads have been incorporated into the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's revamped Hot 100 chart now combines data from sales of music downloads, physical singles, and airplay information. Previously, download sales were only tracked on a separate download chart. Green Day's 'Boulevard of Broken Dreams' is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart and tops its digital chart. The UK singles chart is expected to follow suit later this year, incorporating download sales into its rankings. In the US, digital sales are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. The new Hot 100 chart will tally digital sales with physical singles and airplay information. The Pop 100 chart also combines these metrics, but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music. The inclusion of download sales is a significant change to the chart's methodology.

The net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection after anti-spam laws took a toll on his business. Scott Richter, the man behind OptinRealBig.com, has been involved in sending billions of junk mail messages. He stated that lawsuits have forced the company to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. OptinRealBig was engaged in several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. The company believes that filing for Chapter 11 will aid in resolving its legal issues while allowing it to continue trading. OptinRealBig was listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by Spamhaus, a junk mail watchdog.

Tottenham Sporting Director Frank Arnesen has denied speculation that Coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. Newspaper reports had suggested that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. Arnesen dismissed these claims, stating, "It is absolutely not true." He attributed Santini's resignation to personal problems, saying, "He has spoken to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." Arnesen was unable to provide further insight into the issues that led to Santini's departure after just 13 games in charge. "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was," he said. "But I trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. 

After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight.

Britain's economic future will be at the heart of Labour's poll campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. Following the final cabinet meeting at No 10 before the anticipated election announcement, he expressed confidence that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in bringing stability and growth, and its commitment to continuing this trend. The Tories, meanwhile, have outlined plans to address "yob culture," while the Lib Dems have provided further details on their proposals to replace council tax. In a separate development, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to the three parties, urging them to refrain from exploiting people's fears during the election. He cautioned against transforming the election into a competition focused on who can most effectively instill fear in voters regarding terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA's championships in Sheffield. Notably, US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll, the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans, will not participate in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy aims to secure his place in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in outstanding form on the European circuit in recent weeks, establishing himself as one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter. His performance has already made him a strong contender for a spot in Madrid. Meanwhile, Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European championships. Carroll is currently ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking, with Cragg occupying the top spot.

Jason Robinson, England's rugby union captain, is targeting dual code success over Australia on Saturday. A former rugby league international who switched codes in 2000, Robinson will lead England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. Later, at 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the Tri-Nations tournament final. "Achieving victories in both games would be a massive accomplishment, especially for the league," Robinson stated. England have the opportunity to secure their third autumn international win, following consecutive victories over Canada and South Africa, and gain revenge for the 51-15 loss to the Wallabies in June. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with a win at Elland Road, and beating the Aussies in both games would be a significant achievement.

Net users are being warned to avoid a scam website claiming to collect donations on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate, utilizing an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with the fake site and has reported it to the authorities. This is the latest in a series of scams attempting to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam email currently circulating, with a subject line reading "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal." The email's text is riddled with poor grammar and spelling, characteristic of phishing attempts.

Iraq to Invite Phone Licence Bids. Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licences, with the aim of significantly boosting nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications has extended an invitation to local, Arab, and foreign companies to participate in the bidding process. The winning bidder will form a partnership with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to increase Iraq's telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to 25% within the next 10 years. It also hopes to develop a highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector. The bidding and tender process details will be published on the ministry's website on 9 February.

More women are taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks increased by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for the net security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are resonating with a diverse group of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired individuals. Over the past three years, this demographic has seen an average annual increase of 13.2%. Notably, more retired women (53%) are purchasing security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband internet connections can pose to surfers.
