The rise of DIY radio is marked by podcasts, which can fill the vast storage capacity of an Apple iPod or other digital music players, holding up to 10,000 songs. However, an increasing number of iPod owners are utilizing this space for audio content created by a diverse range of producers. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," with former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry being its most prominent advocate. Although podcasting takes its name from the Apple iPod, it is not necessary to own one to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show created by podcasters, typically from the comfort of their own homes, using a microphone, a PC, and editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them for free.

Andrea Levy, the Orange Prize winner, has secured the Whitbread Novel of the Year award for her book 'Small Island'. This victory positions her as the favourite to win the overall prize, having surpassed Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's 'The Line of Beauty'. Geraldine McCaughrean has claimed the Children's Fiction award for the third time with 'Not the End of the World'. All category winners will proceed to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, accompanied by a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on 25 January to determine the overall winner, with the announcement to be made later that evening.

Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the relatively unknown firm that has acquired its primary asset. The company intends to sue Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will attempt to freeze Baikal's assets, as the Russian government has disregarded a US court order issued last week, which blocked the sale. The background and motivations of Baikal remain unclear. Russian newspapers have alleged that Baikal, which purchased the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion at a state-orchestrated auction on Sunday, has strong ties with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts sealed their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with a convincing 2-1 victory. The home side took an early lead, scoring two goals within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring inside the opening minute, heading a Jamie McAllister free kick over Colin Meldrum and into the net. McAllister himself doubled the lead, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post to put the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a disputed goal after an hour, but Hearts held on to secure the win. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken clumsily fouled Miller 35 yards from goal, resulting in a free kick. McAllister floated the ball into the box, where Miller outjumped the static visiting defence to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossing to the back post where McAllister headed past Meldrum to double the lead.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers to rent massive computing power by the hour. The Sun Grid service charges users $1 per hour for processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. This concept, known as grid computing, is the latest trend in the industry, where computing capacity is viewed as a commodity on par with hardware and software. Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz, likened grid computing to the evolution of electricity, suggesting that the system could mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" Schwartz asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly Network Computing event in California. The service aims to provide customers with flexible and cost-effective access to computing resources.

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, stating her intention to impose severe penalties, including exclusion orders, to tackle sectarianism. These measures are part of the Scottish Executive's campaign to address the issue. Jamieson commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in combating the problem. However, she emphasized that eradicating sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches remains a top priority. The minister's comments came ahead of the Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead. The Scottish Executive has identified sectarianism, long prevalent among certain sections of both clubs' supporters, as a key target. Recently, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Leeds v Saracens (Fri) at Headingley on Friday, 25 February 2000 GMT. The Tykes have bolstered their squad with the loan signings of Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Leeds: Iain Balshaw; Tom Rees, Chris Christophers, Tom Bell, Matt Doherty; Craig McMullen, Andy Dickens; Tom McGee, Rob Rawlinson, Cobus Gerber; Mike Murphy, Mike Palmer (capt), Andy Morgan, Chris Parks, David Popham. Replacements: Ed Kalman, Graham Regan, David Hyde, Jonny Rigney, Chris McMullan, Chris Rock, Peter Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future as the fixed line phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research conducted by handset maker Nokia reveals that an increasing number of people are relying on their mobile phones for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million individuals in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now exclusively use a mobile phone. The primary reason for retaining a fixed line phone is the lower call charges, but most respondents expressed a strong inclination towards a mobile-centric future. The Nokia-sponsored research highlights distinct usage patterns for mobiles and fixed phones. While home phones are preferred for longer conversations, mobile phone calls tend to be shorter, often between mobile users and friends. In the UK, 69% of respondents cited cost as the primary reason for opting for their fixed phone, as it remains cheaper than using a mobile.

A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair to reform the House of Lords by releasing a detailed plan for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, where 70% of members would be elected. Since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats, MPs and peers have failed to reach an agreement on reform. The group is confident it can garner support for removing the remaining 92 hereditary peers. The government previously postponed plans to abolish the remaining hereditary peers, citing low chances of success due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms.

Disappointed Scott makes a solid start. Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a promising debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. Felipe Vivancos won the race, equalling the Spanish record. Robert Kronberg of Sweden took second place, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final.

A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a predetermined date. The plaintiff, a Georgia resident, claims that a chip inside the cartridge informs the printer that it requires refilling, even when it still contains ink. The lawsuit aims to represent all US consumers who have purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer manufacturer, has declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges utilize chip technology to detect low ink levels and notify users when a replacement is necessary. However, the suit alleges that these chips also cause the cartridges to shut down at a predetermined date, regardless of their actual ink levels.

Roxy Music to Perform at Isle of Wight Festival. Roxy Music will join the lineup at the Isle of Wight Music Festival in June, alongside Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. R.E.M. have already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will perform on the Saturday night of the festival. The band is currently working on new material in the studio, marking their first release since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music were formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's Virginia Plain, with other hits including Street Life, Love Is the Drug and the 1981 John Lennon cover, Jealous Guy.

Captains Unite for Rugby Aid Match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is among four Six Nations captains selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad in the IRB Rugby Aid Match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bullock, and Italy's Marco Bortolami will also join the Northern party. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fund-raising match at Twickenham. Woodward expressed his enthusiasm, stating, "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players." This match will provide Woodward with an opportunity to assess his options before announcing the British and Irish Lions touring party, set to visit New Zealand in the summer.

Sideways dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. The film was named Best Film, while Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, alongside his writing partner Jim Taylor. Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen received acting awards for their performances. Sideways is expected to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, honor films produced outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Catalina Sandino Moreno won Best Actress for her role in the Colombian drama Maria Full of Grace. Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for Maria Full of Grace. The Independent Spirit Awards recognize outstanding achievements in independent filmmaking. The ceremony is a celebration of innovative storytelling and exceptional talent. The awards have become a significant indicator of success at the Oscars.

Wal-mart fights back against accusers as two prominent US names launch advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Wal-mart, has taken out over 100 full-page adverts in national newspapers. The group aims to counter criticism regarding its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign to refute "false" claims about its product Prozac. Wal-mart initiated the battle with adverts in newspapers such as The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from company president Lee Scott, stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth". "There are numerous 'urban legends' circulating about Wal-mart, but facts are facts," he emphasized, as the company seeks to address misconceptions and present its side of the story.

At a glance: Tory health checks. The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: 

Individuals moving to the UK from outside the EU to live and work will be subject to health checks. Those planning to stay six months or more and originating from countries with high TB prevalence will be required to undergo a chest x-ray, with further tests if necessary. 

All non-EU nationals seeking to stay a year or more will undergo a comprehensive medical examination, which includes tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test result will automatically lead to visa application rejection. Other conditions will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

Paris promise raises Welsh hopes - has there been a better Six Nations match than Saturday's epic encounter in Paris? The Welsh revival has sparked optimism, with many wondering if it can continue all the way to a first Grand Slam since 1978. These questions are on the minds of not just Wales supporters, but rugby fans worldwide, following a scintillating display in Paris. Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, a member of two Grand Slam-winning sides in the 1970s, described it as "one of the great performances of the past three decades". Martyn Williams, Wales' two-try scorer, called it "one of the most surreal games I have ever played in". A crestfallen France coach, Bernard Laporte, simply observed: "there was a french half and there was a welsh half".

Manchester rock band Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their latest release, Some Cities. The trio has replaced flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the number one spot. Some Cities follows the success of their single Black and White Town, which peaked at number six. In the singles chart, R&B star Nelly has taken the top spot with Over and Over, a collaboration with Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs have all entered the top ten with new singles, alongside Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame, debuted at number three, narrowly beating Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up.

Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to remain with English side Gloucester, despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands that the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but Davies would prefer to stay at Gloucester. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is currently on a one-year contract at Kingsholm. However, he has proven his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. Davies was left without a region after the Celtic Warriors disbanded in the summer, forcing him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he gained match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he had expressed frustration with the way he was treated prior to his move to Gloucester.

Cabinet ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall funds to keep council tax bills down, according to Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In his pre-budget report on Thursday, Gordon Brown reallocated £512m from central to local government budgets. Raynsford acknowledged that he had held "pretty frank discussions" with fellow ministers over the plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must deliver quality services without significant council tax increases. The central government funds are part of a £1bn package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, a crucial goal in a likely general election year.

Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin is set to feature four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, in the UEFA Cup. As the first Arab side to compete in European competition, Bnei Sakhnin will face English Premiership side Newcastle United in the first round. Murambadoro, who gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. Recently relocating to Israel after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic, Murambadoro joins a team that won the Israeli Cup final last season. Based in Sakhnin, near Haifa, the club is known for its strong ethos and high-profile promotion of peace and co-operation within Israel.

A new report suggests that lowering the drink-drive limit could save more lives than initially thought. Research conducted by University College London claims that reducing the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would result in 65 lives saved annually. The findings, published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety, come as MPs prepare to vote on the government's Road Safety Bill. Although the bill includes changes to speeding fines, it does not address the drink-drive limit. The research, led by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, also estimates that a lower limit would lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads compared to 2003, resulting in annual savings of £119m. A previous estimate from a 1998 Department of Transport document suggested that such a move could save 50 lives a year.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm^2 diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512×512 μm^2. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This approach eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC, fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process, consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality was successfully verified in a clinical setting using a 67.5 MeV proton beam.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that these vehicles would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. We propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that incentivizes autonomous vehicles to seek centrally controlled system optimal routing by offering toll savings. In contrast, user equilibrium-seeking autonomous vehicles and human-driven vehicles are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized at the upper level. The lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model, considering a mixed fleet of autonomous and human-driven vehicles.

Advances in optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This capability has not only facilitated the exploration of quantum behavior in larger, more tangible objects but also sparked ideas for utilizing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, as well as precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to a broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals suggested overcoming this limitation by establishing strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems have been reported, but they have yet to access nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews offer customers valuable product evaluations to inform their purchasing decisions. However, these evaluations can be compromised by fake reviews, also known as "spams," created by professional spammers who continually adapt and refine their tactics to evade detection. The ever-evolving nature of spamming strategies makes them difficult to capture, as they can change rapidly over time, vary across spammers and target products, and often remain unknown. Most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which may not be the most effective approach in maintaining trustworthy product evaluations. To address these challenges, we propose a minimax game framework where spammers and spam detectors engage in a competitive dynamic, with goals that extend beyond mere detection accuracy. The Nash equilibria of this game yield stable detectors that are resilient to diverse detection strategies.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employed the Lewis-Riesenfeld method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the Lewis-Riesenfeld invariant. Among this family, we identified a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we examine the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a variable number of components. The nonconvex nature of this function leads to the existence of multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even in cases where the mixture components are well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima exhibit a common structural form, which partially identifies the centers of the true mixture components. Specifically, each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our findings are applicable in scenarios where the true mixture components meet a specific separation condition, and remain valid regardless of whether the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain more precise results, with a clearer understanding of how the separation between components affects the outcome.

We examine the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $x_m$ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, utilizes another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by a dual group $g^t$. The second, Batyrev construction, involves constructing the mirror partner as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a straightforward demonstration of the equivalence of these two constructions.

In this work, a generalization of the study of human gait was developed from existing models in the literature, such as those by Keller and Kockshenev. This hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy with a non-linear description of the mass center's libration movement, aiming to replicate the walk-run transition behavior. The experimental data results for various speed regimes suggest that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory is a significant quantity in quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories at the Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia, to validate the model's findings.

We introduce a novel mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, capable of fully resolving close encounters. This method employs a time regularisation technique, preserving the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. By utilising a high-order mvs scheme, large time steps can be taken when planets are far apart, away from close encounters. Our algorithm successfully resolves near-exact collisions, with mutual separations of a fraction of the physical radius, using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed systems like the solar system. We demonstrate the long-term behaviour of our integrator on a system of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as Mercury and show that for an equivalent cost we obtain much better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In practice, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is highly challenging due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise, demonstrating a notable difference in efficiency.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure that depends solely on its mass and spin. We have developed a general method for extracting the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes, which we apply to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, exhibiting a more complex multipolar structure that offers a means of constraining fuzzball models phenomenologically. Our analysis reveals that all multipole moments are generally larger in absolute value than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only mild constraints on fuzzballs.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time poses significant challenges across various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. A common scenario involves edges representing either short-term interactions, such as messaging, or long-term structural connections, like friendships. In practice, long-term edges are often manually specified by humans, which can be costly and suboptimal for downstream tasks. To address these limitations, we propose a model that leverages temporal point processes and variational autoencoders to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing their communication patterns. By driving between-node feature propagation through temporal attention, our approach offers greater flexibility while avoiding the drawbacks associated with human-specified edges, such as high production costs and suboptimal performance.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. This research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of pcws, given the pcw's design for near-field atom trapping. The long-term goal is to establish strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the gms of the pcw, thereby enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between these groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. This splitting is of interest in equivariant stable homotopy theory, where the equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor. Consequently, the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. The splittings have implications for the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$, particularly for the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$.

Baryonic feedback effects result in a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum at small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are significant sources of uncertainty for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys, such as Euclid or LSST. In the first of a two-part series, we utilize simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset for the cosmic shear power spectrum and its corresponding covariance matrix, both corrected for baryonic effects using the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). We also develop an emulator to rapidly predict baryonic power suppression, enabling a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\lambda$CDM cosmology incorporating both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, are notoriously difficult to process. However, developing speech processing models that can handle a wide range of conditions would be highly beneficial for language acquisition studies. Researchers in this field are interested in the quantity and quality of speech that children hear and produce. Moreover, such models can aid in early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. We gathered diverse child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings and covering 10 languages, to support this endeavor.

Density-based clustering is based on the concept of linking groups to specific features of the underlying probability distribution. By referencing a true, yet unknown, population structure, the clustering problem can be framed in a standard inferential setting. Here, ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between groups and the domains of attraction of density modes. To implement this approach, a nonparametric density estimate is necessary, and proper selection of the smoothing amount is crucial in shaping the density and identifying the final partition. The amount of smoothing governs the density's shape and possibly its modal structure. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimensional operators that parameterize the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes pose an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction to cancel. Careful measurement of the azimuthal decay angles can "resurrect" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable generated solely by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a primary objective of numerous data analyses in the health and social sciences. Despite this, academic statistics has traditionally been skeptical of data analyses with a causal focus. The emergence of the term "data science" presents a unique opportunity to redefine data analysis, allowing it to seamlessly incorporate causal inference from observational data. We categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three task classes: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction, which encompasses causal inference. A clear classification of data science tasks is essential for discussing the data, assumptions, and analytics required for each task. The failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science, and we argue that this oversight must be addressed.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) necessitates the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The conventional understanding is that these particles ensure extremal black holes are unstable or marginally stable, but the implications of deviating from this are unclear. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems regarding entanglement entropy. Resolving this contradiction yields a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which aligns with the standard statement at weak coupling. The argument is broadly applicable, relying solely on the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography, without invoking supersymmetry or a specific UV completion.

Understanding the emergence of unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures in strongly correlated two-dimensional systems is a major unsolved problem in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as ideal model systems to study the interplay between strong correlations and reduced dimensionality. However, direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been lacking. We demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. Our measurement of v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength reveals a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. This finding establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a valuable tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids, providing new insights into this phenomenon.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) serve as a fundamental mathematical model in various application areas, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to their intuitive appeal in modeling complex systems. Despite their widespread use, the frequent absence of analytical solutions makes it challenging to estimate ODE parameters from data, particularly when dealing with models that have numerous variables and parameters. This paper presents a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is both fast and accurate, even for models with a large number of parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model using a state-space model based on the equations of a numerical solver. By avoiding the computation of the entire numerical solution in the likelihood, it enables fast estimation. The posterior is obtained using a variational Bayes method, specifically the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions comprising a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. The differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes exhibit a strong dependence on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. A chiral chemical potential, resulting from the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, significantly influences the junction's transport characteristics. Notably, a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs, generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions, is observed. The spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a concern for the use of this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of as much as 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity shows only a very slow decrease of about 10% over the following year, maintaining its effectiveness over time.

We introduce a novel Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, grounded in the concept of hidden local symmetry. This current's associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Furthermore, singular configurations can be identified as n_f=1 baryons, which are charged under the new symmetry. In this context, vector mesons assume the role of Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current provides the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal offers a unified picture for the two types of baryons, enabling their continuous transformation into one another in a natural manner. The Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents a unique opportunity to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. Theoretically, we investigate how the superposition of these effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates substantial transverse Hall supercurrents, which we term anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. By generalizing the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially established to quantify conventional Josephson current flows, we assess the transverse current components and show that their amplitudes can be extensively tuned via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction.

Following the suggestion from Monte-Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. Turbul., 2020), which indicate that dipoles play a crucial role in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence, comparable to individual vortex cores, it is discovered that the kinetic energy of this flow is primarily carried by elongated streams formed through the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into two distinct families: small, fast-moving cores and larger, slowly moving ones that can be described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both families are very different, and only the former is self-similar. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams.

Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for designing several quantum algorithms. The running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is often characterized by the quantum hitting time, which is the time required for the quantum walk to locate a vertex of interest with a high probability. This article presents improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to various ctqw-based quantum algorithms. Notably, our techniques are applied to the glued-trees problem, yielding a polynomial factor improvement in the hitting time upper bound, from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Our methods also enhance the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm for finding a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized into dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their distinct formation mechanisms. Dry EMRIs, previously considered the primary EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily generated through multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. This letter highlights an alternative EMRI formation channel: wet EMRI formation facilitated by the accretion flow surrounding accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, significantly boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically lack information about them, including interaction history with items, user profiles, and social connections with other users. Despite this, we expect our recommender systems to engage users from the outset, encouraging them to stay and become active users. This challenge falls under the new user cold-start category, which is vital to a company's development and survival. Existing approaches to addressing user cold-start recommendation often require additional user effort, such as setting up an interview process, or rely on supplementary information like user demographics, locations, and social relationships. However, users may be unwilling to participate in interviews, and such side information is usually unavailable for cold-start users. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, e.g. Setting up an interview process, or make use of side information such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc.

Deep learning has resolved numerous problems that were previously inaccessible to heuristic algorithms. Its successful application in wireless communications is notable, particularly given the well-understood nature of current radio systems and the existence of optimal algorithms for many tasks. Although learning individual components of a receiver has yielded some benefits, a more effective approach involves jointly learning the entire receiver. However, this often results in a complex nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is impractical to implement. To address this challenge, we introduce a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which processes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal streams to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. By carefully constructing the input of the convolutional neural network using both data and pilot symbols, we enable accurate channel estimation.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically generates new inputs by mutating an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs, known as a corpus. However, a corpus often contains thousands of similar inputs, resulting in a lack of diversity that can lead to inefficient fuzzing efforts due to exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To mitigate this issue, fuzzers are equipped with distillation tools, such as afl-cmin, which select the smallest subset of seeds that trigger the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Minimizing the number and cumulative size of seeds is believed to lead to more efficient fuzzing. We systematically investigate this notion and present the results of over 34 cpu-years of fuzzing using five distillation approaches to understand their impact on bug detection in real-world software.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation, where agents can be grouped based on similar state transition structures, allowing them to be relabeled into a unified template. A scalable supervisor is designed, with a state size and computational cost independent of the number of agents, for the case of partial observation. Notably, this supervisor does not require recomputation when agents are added or removed from the system. We extend our previous results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis, demonstrating its effectiveness in multi-agent systems.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations serve as a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. A novel approach for ENF estimation is presented, utilizing temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. This method leverages a type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix, taking advantage of its Toeplitz structure. Notably, this approach introduces, for the first time in ENF analysis, a non-rectangular temporal window preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices facilitate efficient matrix inversions. The proposed method surpasses existing state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation when employing a 1-second time window in power recordings. In speech recordings, the approach yields highly accurate results, balancing time complexity and accuracy. The method's efficiency and accuracy make it a valuable contribution to the field of ENF analysis.

The direpack package integrates modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python universe as a single, consistent package. It categorizes dimension reduction methods into three groups: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, the package provides regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces, including classical principal component regression and sparse partial robust M regression. The package also includes classical and robust pre-processing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Direpack is designed to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, allowing estimators to seamlessly integrate into statistical and machine learning pipelines within that framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we investigated the anomalous saturating effect of nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. High-power laser excitation led to fluorescence reduction, increasing the nonlinearity of fluorescence emission and altering the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. A differential excitation protocol was employed to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high power laser excitation. It increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, and changed the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights, constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities, to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution, which achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. In contrast to frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, our approach uniquely achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the bayesian modeling paradigm and provides a bridge across the two rich but disparate sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, including res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, exhibit more complex atomistic structures compared to the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. Their reduced symmetries lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, and magnetism. Additionally, these materials display spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. The special topic "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" showcases recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials, highlighting their unique electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations.

Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. Notably, it was discovered that the relaxation of electric birefringence in a mesogenic polymer melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, with two dominant processes playing a crucial role. These primary processes replace each other within a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also revealed two distinct orientational relaxation processes: one attributed to the rotation of side mesogenic groups, and the other associated with the motion of main chain segments, providing a more detailed understanding of the polymer's behavior.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated exceptional retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits remains a key focus in these methods. A common approach involves employing an activation function, such as sigmoid or tanh, and minimizing a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm can lead to an increasing number of hash bits becoming stuck in the wrong saturated area of the activation functions, from which they never escape. We refer to this issue as the "dead bits problem" (dbp). Furthermore, existing quantization losses can exacerbate dbp. In this paper, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier that precedes activation functions to mitigate dbp.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider two scenarios: the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or they decay via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The stable triplet scenario is constrained by LHC disappearing charged track searches and dark matter direct detection experiments. The unstable triplet scenario is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. Our findings indicate that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches. In contrast, an unstable triplet with a mass below 230 GeV is excluded at a 95% confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings surrounding the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than anticipated in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, also known as "pericenter glow." The standard scenario assumes an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. A minor modification to this scenario suggests that narrower belts can form if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, potentially resulting from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could also be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.

An electron is typically considered to possess only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, due to its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well-captured at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-Liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations. Furthermore, three additional 1D 'replica' modes emerge, strengthening with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1D inter-subband screening, which is adjusted by over 45%.

The assembly history of the Milky Way is being unveiled through data from the Gaia mission. The globular cluster system of our galaxy likely followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this path, we investigate the link between globular clusters and known merging events experienced by the Milky Way. We combined Gaia's kinematic information for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest sample of cluster ages, carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a crucial step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces intrinsic, an R package that implements state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of a dataset's intrinsic dimension. The package includes the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To facilitate easy access to these novel estimators, the package provides high-level, intuitive functions built on a set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models in two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The homogeneous category comprises the two-nn and gride models, with functions that perform inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The heterogeneous category includes hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented. The package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic dimension estimators are categorized into two categories.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, holding promise for enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems were proposed and modeled: one based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and the other on 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system predictions, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNO to current pulse stimulation revealed that an RC system utilizing a single MSM achieved outstanding performance in handwritten digits recognition. Furthermore, a physical RC system comprising 24 STNOs effectively solved complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems, as confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are pivotal in online platforms, including search engines and recommender systems. This paper reveals a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: when fewer items report a given signal, they collectively attract a higher share of overall traffic. The few-get-richer effect arises in settings with few distinct item classes, such as left-leaning versus right-leaning news sources, where items are ranked by popularity. Analytically, we demonstrate that this effect emerges when users tend to click on top-ranked items and exhibit heterogeneous preferences for item classes. Through simulations, we examine how the effect's strength varies with setting and human behavior assumptions. We experimentally test our predictions in an online study with human participants. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the spread of misinformation. The few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as a straightforward and effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), resulting in accelerated performance across various platforms. However, most pruning techniques involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we propose a novel sparsity dimension, pattern-based sparsity, which combines pattern and connectivity sparsity to achieve both high accuracy and hardware friendliness. By carefully designing patterns, our pruning approach consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and improved feature extraction capabilities across different DNN structures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework simultaneously performs pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training. The new pattern-based sparsity naturally lends itself to compiler optimization, enabling highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that significantly differs from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have disparate effects on the groups. To mitigate this, constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group can result in reduced bias. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. We examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. By constructing a more closely matched control group for a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we found a 95% confidence interval that encompasses substantial adverse effects, no effect, and small beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulation purposes, it is essential to assess their ability to accurately reproduce the data. This evaluation can be performed using visual predictive checks (VPCs), which involve (1) simulating the original study multiple times from the model being evaluated, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of these estimates with the original study's estimate. This procedure is a widely applicable, straightforward method. In this context, we explore its application to time-to-event data, focusing on the specific scenario where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems through sequential schemes are presented. We explore how similar protocols, leveraging repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can facilitate: (i) confinement and protection of quantum dynamics from decoherence, aligning with Zeno physics principles. (ii) analytical prediction of the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state via stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimal reconstruction of environmental noise sources' spectral density by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain, driving the designed quantum sensor. These advancements will enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, driving progress in quantum science and technologies.

It's rare to find someone with a single interest that they want to pursue for the rest of their life. The modern work landscape reflects this diversity, with around 15 percent of American workers opting for non-traditional arrangements, such as part-time, contract, or temporary positions. The term "side hustle" has become synonymous with this ethos, where individuals combine multiple pursuits to make a living. The phrase "side hustle" originated in popular African American newspapers in the 1920s, initially referring to scams. However, by the 1950s, it also encompassed legitimate work. A side hustle differs from a second job, which is often driven by necessity.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her. Michelangelo once said that when he gazed at raw marble, he envisioned a figure yearning to be set free. The chisel was his sole tool. However, living organisms are not chiseled; they grow. Our cells, the smallest units of life, contain all the necessary information for every other cell to function and replicate. Tools also have consequences. Since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production, but living things are not chiseled, they grow.

Hello, my name is Simone. You're likely familiar with the advice to imagine the audience naked when feeling nervous onstage. However, picturing everyone in their birthday suits in 2018 seems somewhat outdated and off-putting. We're striving to move beyond such tactics, so it's time to explore alternative methods for managing stage nerves. I've come to realize that I'd prefer a more reciprocal dynamic – to be able to observe you just as you're observing me, thereby creating a sense of balance. If I had multiple eyeballs, we'd all feel more at ease, wouldn't we?

To do two things at once is to do neither." This phrase, often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, serves as a scathing critique of multitasking. Although its origin is uncertain, the statement's validity is worth exploring. While it's undoubtedly true for emailing during dinner, texting while driving, or live tweeting at a TED Talk, I'd like to argue that for a specific type of activity, doing multiple things simultaneously is precisely what we should strive for. Consider Albert Einstein, who in 1905, published four groundbreaking scientific papers, showcasing his remarkable ability to excel in multiple areas concurrently.

I know this may sound unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. Growing up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the former home of Bethlehem Steel, had a profound impact on me. My father, an engineer, would often explain how things worked, and we would collaborate on projects, such as model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart we built together - that's me behind the wheel, with my sister and best friend at the time. One day, when I was around 10 years old, my father came home and announced at the dinner table that our next project would be building a robot. A robot.

Sustainability encompasses the what, where, and how of seafood production. However, I believe the who and why are equally crucial. I'm interested in learning about the people behind my dinner choices and the impact I have on them, as well as the impact they have on me. I want to understand their motivations for fishing and how they rely on the ocean's resources for their livelihood. By grasping these aspects, we can transform our perception of seafood from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. This shift allows us to appreciate the seafood we're fortunate to eat. So, what do we call this approach? I propose the term 'restorative seafood.' While sustainability refers to the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative seafood is about replenishing and progressing.

The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel, the spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress, and the stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of Christmas past remain recognizable figures from Charles Dickens' work, more than a century after his death. His body of work is so striking that it has given rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens' writing that make it so special? Dickens' fiction is characterized by anticipation, built through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features kept his audience engaged. Initially, his stories were serialized in affordable literary journals, released a few chapters at a time, and later reprinted as books.

Shah Rukh Khan: Courage, determination, and a single-minded vision are the qualities that the biggest achievers share. These brave hearts view failure as an unacceptable outcome. What appears to us as an insurmountable challenge, our next speaker sees as an irresistible stage she was born to conquer. Let's delve into the story of our fearless speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who's making a splash in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti Sharma. (applause) Bhakti Sharma: Imagine a two-and-a-half-year-old riding on a moped behind her mom on a scorching summer afternoon in Rajasthan, unaware of their destination. Twenty minutes later, that same child finds herself completely submerged in water.

I'd like to discuss a cutting-edge technology currently being developed at Oxford, which we believe has the potential to revolutionize the creation of computer games and Hollywood movies. This technology involves simulating humans, complete with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control it. Before delving deeper into this technology, let's take a brief look at the current state of human characters in computer games. We have a clip from the game "Grand Theft Auto 3," which we touched on yesterday. As you can see, it's a highly acclaimed game, and one of the most successful of all time. Now, before I talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3.

Like many people worldwide, my friends and I were captivated by the Women's World Cup in France earlier this summer. We were enthralled by the incredible athletes, the remarkable goals, and the clean, engaging games. Meanwhile, off the field, these women were advocating for equal pay, and in some countries, any pay at all for their sport. Due to our mild obsession, we sought to watch the games live and opted for a Spanish-speaking network in the US as our starting point. It wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend pointed out, "Why does it seem like all I'm seeing are commercials for makeup, household cleaning products, and diets?

You've been falsely accused of a crime, with no means to prove your innocence. Insisting on your innocence may lead to a guilty verdict and execution. However, confessing, apologizing, and implicating others could secure your freedom. Do you give a false confession or risk a public hanging? Where does all the released carbon go? Carbon operates within a natural cycle, present in all living organisms: in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and deep underground rocks. When plants and other living organisms die, a significant portion of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb it. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life transforms into rock and fossil fuels, such as coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events, like volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon trapped in rock. Human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels, also release prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release approximately 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year, while the natural cycle of carbon continues with plants and other living things dying, and new ones growing and reabsorbing the carbon.
